texts.definition: Variation in gameplay for a game, either within a single play session or between different play sessions.
markups: <style="Definition">Variation in gameplay for a game, either within a single play session or between different play sessions.</style>

Games that never vary in what is possible to do don't let players have choices or even influence. For this reason games typically offer variety but this is naturally limited due to games having rule sets that dictate what actions are possible. Even so, players can experience that some games allow for quite different gameplay experiences and choices while others don't. Those that do are said to have <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Settlers%20of%20Catan">Settlers of Catan</link></style> allows for randomizing its hexes to provide different setups each time it is played. Similarly, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Rogue">Rogue</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style> uses randomness to make their levels be different each time players play them.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Slaves%20to%20Armok%20II:%20Dwarf%20Fortress">Slaves to Armok II: Dwarf Fortress</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unexplored">Unexplored</link></style> takes this a step further and uses procedural content generation to create their worlds and levels respectively. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%2040K">Warhammer 40K</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Magic:%20The%20Gathering">Magic: The Gathering</link></style> supports <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> through letting players bring varied sets of game elements to each game instance; <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominion">Dominion</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mystic%20Vale">Mystic Vale</link></style> instead provides this variety from decks of cards that players acquire during gameplay.

Each turn in any of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fluxx%20series">Fluxx series</link></style> can change the rules controlling how players can act in the games. While the possibility space of rules is fixed in these, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Nomic">Nomic</link></style> allows each players' turn to introduce completely new rules to the game (or change or remove existing ones).

Game systems like <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Basic%20Role-Playing">Basic Role-Playing</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> allows for <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> simply because players (or rather game masters) can create their own specific games using these. The standard 52-card deck is another example of this since it supports many different games.

Games can be seen as not being varied even if they provide many different types of actions, choices, or goals. This is because players may perceive large scale patterns that negate the variations in detail or since they may feel that the local variations have no significant impact on how gameplay develops. For this reason, <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/:category:Subjective%20Patterns">Subjective Pattern</link></style> whose presence can really only be determined over time. That said, one of the most general ways of ensuring <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> within a game instance is to vary the rules that apply in that instance. This can either simply be by having <style="Link"><link="varying-rule-sets">Varying Rule Sets</link></style> but an alternative is to have <style="Link"><link="evolving-rule-sets">Evolving Rule Sets</link></style>. In general, <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> is a way to promote <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style>. This can be done both within and between game instances, for example through applying <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> on <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ephemeral-goals">Ephemeral Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>. For <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> specifically, <style="Link"><link="procedurally-generated-game-worlds">Procedurally Generated Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Constructed%20Worlds">Player Constructed Worlds</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="reconfigurable-game-worlds">Reconfigurable Game Worlds</link></style> can be used to make these vary between game instances. Another general approach to support <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> is to allow players choices since each choice can provide more variation. While this means that <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style> can be used in general, a <style="Link"><link="selectable-set-goals">Selectable Set of Goals</link></style> provides a clear enumeration of what choices exist while <style="Link"><link="incompatible-goals">Incompatible Goals</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style> force players to choice between goals. <style="Link"><link="geometric-progression">Geometric Progression</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="negative-feedback-loops">Negative Feedback Loops</link></style> can make continued efforts towards similar goals less useful and thereby encourage players to vary themselves concerning what goals they choose to strive towards (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diminishing%20Returns">Diminishing Returns</link></style> can serve a similar purpose). When several players play together, their choices and interaction can provide even more variation due to social and psychological effects. This means that patterns dealing with creating shifting relations between game agents, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dynamic%20Alliances">Dynamic Alliances</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>, make for <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> (<style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> can also make players find other goals to avoid conflicts and thereby encourage players to make use of the variety in goals that exists). To a lesser degree, this can also be achieved by giving players <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style>, and somewhat paradoxically <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> can be used for this also since they can guarantee different behaviors to the other players of a game. Besides these general approaches there are two main categories of <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style>: that which is varied between game instances and that which is varied within game instances. A game can of course aspire to provide both.

<style="Link"><link="asymmetric-gameplay">Asymmetric Gameplay</link></style> in general promotes <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style>, be it through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Abilities">Asymmetric Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-goals">Asymmetric Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-resource-distribution">Asymmetric Resource Distribution</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-resource-distribution">Asymmetric Resource Distribution</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Roles">Asymmetric Roles</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-starting-conditions">Asymmetric Starting Conditions</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style> (between players' abilities) and <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> also typically provide <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> between game instances through giving players different <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> each time they play (limited by the number of different <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> that are varied). This can be packaged as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Roles">Asymmetric Roles</link></style> and in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> this can take the form of <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style>. With enough different types of game elements, games using <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Magic:%20The%20Gathering">Magic: The Gathering</link></style>), <style="Link"><link="card-building">Card Building</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mystic%20Vale">Mystic Vale</link></style>), or <style="Link"><link="deck-building">Deck Building</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominion">Dominion</link></style>) more or less guarantees that there will be [Varied Gameplay]] at least on a mechanical level (general play styles and phases may still be very similar between game instances). <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> in general can support <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> but more likely between players than for individual players. <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style> lets players have difference between game instances in that they can use different routes to achieve their goals between the instances. <style="Link"><link="back-back-game-sessions">Back-to-Back Game Sessions</link></style> can be used to any game design that has <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> between game instances to further provide <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> although this is most often used in games with <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-starting-conditions">Asymmetric Starting Conditions</link></style> to create <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> over game instances.

During game instances <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> can be forced on players through <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="cooldown">Cooldown</link></style> effects since these can make players have to handle challenges in different ways during a game instance. More positively from the players' perspective, <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> can be achieved by presenting them with <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> (possibly through access to new <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>), <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sidegrades">Sidegrades</link></style>, new or improved <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="temporary-abilities">Temporary Abilities</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="vision-modes">Vision Modes</link></style>. Letting players meet or control different <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> is another way to give <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> to them, possibly through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style>. In more general terms, having <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style> among the various game elements encountered in a game. For games with <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>, giving <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> to these provide players with <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> in that they get more and more options of what to do as gameplay progresses. When it comes to varying goals within a game instance, <style="Link"><link="ephemeral-goals">Ephemeral Goals</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="minigames">Minigames</link></style> can do this and thereby make players have different gameplay during a game instance. While not introducing new goals, both <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="testing-achievements">Testing Achievements</link></style> can make players try other types of goals than the ones they typically focus on.

<style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> on a more abstract level promotes <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> since players may both need to handle more different types of challenges (and have more different actions available) and need to vary their style of playing overtime. <style="Link"><link="polyathlons">Polyathlons</link></style> can be seen as a special case of this through dividing a game into several different parts which each require different skills. One way of making <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> through <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> is having many <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> in a game and providing players with possibilities of using <style="Link"><link="converters">Converters</link></style> or combinations of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Producer-Consumer">Producer-Consumer</link></style> actions on them. Having different phases is another way of having <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> in a game, for example through the use of patterns such as <style="Link"><link="construction-scoring-phase-shift">Construction/Scoring Phase Shift</link></style> or games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Planning%20Phases">Planning Phases</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Execution%20Phases">Execution Phases</link></style>, or both.

<style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> can be used to provide <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> both through having individual <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> differ from each other (through structure, variety in content, and varying rules) and by differing internally (for example through <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>). Variations in <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> are a very common solution for <style="Link"><link="levels">Level</link></style> variation, e.g. by giving <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> to some <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> or by giving <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> to <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="backtracking-levels">Backtracking Levels</link></style> is a production efficient way of proving <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> over a <style="Link"><link="levels">Level</link></style> as long as it isn't symmetric. <style="Link"><link="tile-laying">Tile-Laying</link></style> can be used as a way to vary <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, as consequences of players' actions, <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>, or procedural content generation. Player quite naturally experience <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> between game instances when those instances have <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> which players create through <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style>.

Varying players' <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, the challenges, or the game elements in a game can all promote <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style>. However, this typically also promotes <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style>, so ensuring that a game has <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style> often works as a way of making <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> be present in a game design. This is even more certain in games that also encourage <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style>.

Some patterns work against <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style>. Ones that make players do less or make them do the same most of the time belong to this group. Examples include <style="Link"><link="camping">Camping</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="entrenching-gameplay">Entrenching Gameplay</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Symmetry">Symmetry</link></style> in general remove variety, so <style="Link"><link="symmetric-goals">Symmetric Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Symmetric%20Information">Symmetric Information</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="symmetric-resource-distribution">Symmetric Resource Distribution</link></style> all work against <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quick%20Games">Quick Games</link></style> works against the patterns simply because it may be difficult to have variety in a short game. While <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sensory-Motoric%20Engrossment">Sensory-Motoric Engrossment</link></style> doesn't work against <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style>, <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> works against players being able to have that particular type of engrossment.

<style="Link"><link="alien-space-bats">Alien Space Bats</link></style> can be used to introduce or point players towards areas of a game where <style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> exists due to the introduction of new elements to the diegesis.

<style="CurrentLink">Varied Gameplay</style> can make games have <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> since players need to be able to handle shifting contexts (besides how challenging the actual activities are). This naturally affect how easy it is to have <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> of such a game.

<style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="alien-space-bats">Alien Space Bats</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Abilities">Asymmetric Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-gameplay">Asymmetric Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="camping">Camping</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="entrenching-gameplay">Entrenching Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quick%20Games">Quick Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sensory-Motoric%20Engrossment">Sensory-Motoric Engrossment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="symmetric-goals">Symmetric Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Symmetric%20Information">Symmetric Information</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="symmetric-resource-distribution">Symmetric Resource Distribution</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Symmetry">Symmetry</link></style>
